settings.text: Willow Crossley is a florist, author, designer and mother. She is the owner of an intimate British brand in the Cotswolds, which consists of various floral workshops, private styling, published literature and much more. Read on to find out more about Willow Crossley and her love of flowers.

settings.grid-content:
How would you describe your style? 

Colourful, relaxed and comfortable. Being comfortable is my first priority.  I’m not good in anything tight or restrictive.  I love a jean or a mini shirt with a beautiful, over sized jumper and a biker boot.

settings.title: What are your favourite pieces from the new AW21 collection?
settings.text: I love the navy cardigan with the yellow elbows. You had a jumper like this years ago which I have literally loved to death. I was so excited to discover it’s back again - and there’s a jumper too - That’s basically my winter wardrobe sorted!  You’ve also got an over sized dark green cashmere jumper which I know I’ll live in.  It’s a great shape and a fab alternative colour to navy which I am worryingly addicted to!

settings.grid-title: What are some of your favourite flowers and bouquet combinations you have created in the past?
settings.grid-content: At this time of year, I love a mad dahlia mix, Thomas A Eddison, Santa Claus, Blue Bayou and Tartan mixed in with lots of attar of roses geranium leaf.  A spring favourite is foxgloves, Solomon seal, guelder rose and white dicentra.  Or Solomon Seal, Pheasants eye daffodils, mad stripy tulips and early spring branches.

settings.title: Has floristry affected your style and your home?
settings.text: Our house is always over run with plants and flowers - dried, fresh, potted anything I can get my hands on, there’s always a lot of left overs from jobs or something that im experimenting with. I find a house feels unloved without some sort of natural treasure.

settings.grid-title: What are your top 3 tips for creating an Autumnal bunch of flowers?
settings.grid-content:
Try and source your flowers locally. Seasonal, locally grown flowers will always be the best quality and last the longest.  Have a look at the website, Flowers from the Farm to find your nearest grower.  Use a mix of shapes in your arrangements to create a good balance.  I wouldn’t suggest using more that 7 varieties though.  Foliage is just as important as the flowers to me. Beach leaf is still in great condition at this time of year, As is jasmine, senecio, Passion flower and geranium leaf.   Dahlias and some of the beautiful chrysanthemums are great as the leading ladies.  Old mans beard is a beautiful foliage, just remove the leaves if you’re not going to use it in water. 

How would you describe your personal style?
Varied. For work I like a good shirt and trousers combo but also a great floaty dress. At home I swing from cashmere or Adidas tracksuits up to full glam depending on the mood. I love getting dressed up, if there isn’t somewhere to go then I’ll just dress up at home and have cocktails.

settings.title: How does Autumn make you feel? Best memories?
settings.text: Autumn is definitely about getting cosy.  I love nothing more than hunkering down with a fire, red wine and a box set with Charlie.  Long crispy, sunny walks and long pub lunches.  One of my favourite memories was going to London with my brothers and parents when we were small and buying roasted chestnuts on the street. I must have been about 10 and thought I’d died and gone to heaven. That delicious, hot, smoky scent, the crinkly paper bag and being out way past my bedtime. I’ve never forgotten it.
